reasoning: First, GOOG is a brilliant operation in the online advertising and cloud arena, but it lies outside my circle of competence. I’ve built my track record on consumer staples, insurance, railroads and simple industrials; complex software platforms—except Apple’s ecosystem—aren’t my game. Second, Google does possess a moat: dominant search market share, network effects in data collection and ad pricing power. Third, management under Sundar Pichai appears capable, with sensible capital allocation and substantial buybacks, but I lack the granular insight to judge long‐term incentives and R&D trade-offs. Fourth, its balance sheet seems fortress-like—huge cash piles, consistent cash flow—but I can’t vouch for hidden capital commitments or regulatory reserves with the limited data. Fifth, with no reliable intrinsic value or margin of safety calculations here, and likely trading at rich multiples, price risk is high. Sixth, long‐term prospects in AI and cloud are exciting, but antitrust headwinds and rapid tech shifts are real red flags. Finally, compared to opportunities in my portfolio—from Coca-Cola’s defensible brand to BNSF’s steady cash flows—GOOG just isn’t where I’d place Berkshire’s capital. When in doubt, I step aside.
